Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Acoustic Camera for Multidisciplinary Research and Teaching at Dartmouth College
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Dartmouth College to acquire an acoustic camera for tracking sources of sound in video. The acoustic camera will contribute to multidisciplinary research, teaching and outreach. A teaching module will be developed on the acoustics of natural landscapes using the acoustic camera that can be customized and incorporated into graduate courses, undergraduate courses and teacher training for professional development days. Dartmouth's Science & Technology Outreach team will assist with delivering products from the acoustic camera to the broader community, such as interactive audiovisual depictions of songbird choruses for the Hubbard Brook LTER web portal, movies from research on the acoustics of bats, frogs and primates to present at a local science pub, and audiovisual displays for the website of a National Public Radio special series on sounds in nature.

Sound recordings provide rich information about natural systems and human environments. A major limitation of acoustic recordings, however, is that they do not provide information about the direction or location of the sound source. An acoustic camera is a cutting-edge instrument that integrates both visual and acoustic information to generate video images that identify the direction and source of sounds using a video camera, microphone array, data acquisition board and processing computer. At Dartmouth, there is an unusually large and interdisciplinary community of people united by an interest in acoustics and natural sounds. The acquisition of an acoustic camera will elevate the individual research and teaching programs of multiple faculty in multiple disciplines who study the transmission and identity of sounds in the environment. Furthermore, the acoustic camera will foster cross-disciplinary collaborations among faculty in Biology, Anthropology, Music, and other disciplines. Current projects across the university address the role of sounds in evolutionary processes. These projects range from the dynamics and evolutionary drivers of social interactions in acoustically signaling animals, to the role of soundscapes in the evolution of human hearing, language and music. The ability to assign sounds to individuals within aggregations or pairwise interactions in field conditions will enable researchers to answer unresolved questions for a variety of projects across disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wood Frogs:

Acoustic cameras (https://www.acoustic-camera.com/) were originally developed for use in industrial quality control and noise reduction. Localizing aberrant sounds produced from noise-emitting machinery (e.g., wind turbines, diesel engines) or from inside enclosed spaces (e.g. car interiors) allows engineers to localize and reduce noise levels. To our knowledge, ours is the first research that is capitalizing on the simultaneous visual and acoustic outputs from this technology to advance our understanding of biological processes in nature.

 

Acoustic cameras integrate a digital video-camera with a microphone array to map sound onto acoustic still or video images. Our array consists of 48 separate microphones recording on independent channels with a focal distance that ranges from one to ten meters. The camera and array are connected to a field-portable laptop computer powered by a 12-volt battery with an inverter. The camera is locked to a standard tri-pod and placed at the pool edge nearest the chorus. Long ethernet cables (50m) allow us to remain inconspicuous after the initial set-up is complete and a typical chorus resumes within about 45 minutes of this disturbance. During the course of this award, we systematically made three recordings of two-minutes each at 12 different populations of wood frogs. Sound recordings are gathered along with spatial information through a process called ?beam forming? in which sound paths (pressure waves) become visible on a computer screen in real time (Figure 1). Video and audio recordings were analyzed using software (Noiseimage) provided with the acoustic camera. Although all of our sound analyses included traditional bioacoustics measurements like peak frequency, bandwidth, and 90% call duration for the males in each chorus, deeper insights were made available in the spatial and temporal aspects of sound production. The spectrograms we recorded at pools provide precise locations from which sounds originate on a frame by frame basis, allowing us to assign sound files to individual frogs, even in cases where multiple individuals call simultaneously. We are now analysing these data to assess the joint roles of individual male calls and the importance of group dynamics as they interact to influence variation in social interactions and reproductive success.

Initial results from these measures are proving very exciting. Populations of calling males varied from 19-164 males (mean=80.18?16) and the number of egg-masses laid at each pond was correlated with numbers of calling males (r2=0.41, df=11, P=0.03). After correcting for the numbers of individual males calling at each pond, residual egg-masse counts were significantly higher in ponds where choruses had both low frequency and low variance in calling frequency compared to other types of ponds (ANOVA F1,9=6.46, P=0.03).

 

We are now working on manuscripts that will provide the first investigation into how individual-level variation in bioacoustic signals contribute to chorus dynamics and the subsequent probability of mating opportunities in a pond-breeding amphibian. Take together, our results suggest that female wood frogs prefer choruses that are low in both frequency and low variance. Moreover, males appear sensitive to the bioacoustics properties of other pond residents and cue in on their nearest neighbor to time their calls.

 

Bats, Birds, and Kaydids:

The covid crisis stymied all travel to remote field locatinos and so aside from the work we have done on frogs, all other work is currently on hold. We do play to restart these projects as soon as possible.
